Anonymous Sun 02 Aug 2020 14:04:41 No.31870406 Report
Quoted By: >>31870560 >>31870637 >>31870842
>>31870210
>...most species with huge tails would probably either amputate it at infanthood or have a massive bias towards ranged combat as armor get more elaborate and important.
No or light armor. Speed and agility make up for many other flaws if tech is below the level of firearms.
>Because armor covering the tail would be both ridiculously intricate and finicky work and really heavy.
As above, so the aim would be minimal encumbrance. In order to impart damage you require one of a few methods. Squaring up and allowing the maximum transmission of force, creating leverage with a limb extension apparatus (see spear or spear thrower for reference), or by speed (good old mass times acceleration).
>So warrior classes would probably be tailless or go all out on the elf cliche.
The sole point is that the tail would be an evolutionary advantage that allows them to move in way a human couldn't.
>At a later stage common laborers would probably suffer the same thing. Early industrial machines were really hazardous pieces of work and claimed many lives and limbs.
This I agree with in part. No matter what protections existed, mutilations would happen, but those same mutilations would have been possible with lower text equipment. Unless your setting involves rapid tech expansion to a lower level society, this would be in the range of what humanity faced.
>How much worse would it be for a species with a huge protruding limb sprouting out in the exact opposite direction from most of their sensory apparatus.
And here you lose. Any amateur athlete vastly improves their sense of proprioception. You don't need eyes to judge where parts of your body are in a three dimensional space because the neuromusculoskelatal system relays that information to the brain. In short, the mass of the tail would feedback its position via gravitational/acceleration stress on the core of the body. If I can bench press with my eyes closed, then a tail works in a similar fashion.
Anonymous

  • Report

Anonymous Sun 02 Aug 2020 14:05:32 No.31870416 Report
Quoted By:
>>31870210
I feel like trails are forgotten in a lot of settings. They're used to communicate, but that doesn't make as much sense for bipedals that effectively hide their tails behind them. They're used for maintaining balance, but that effectively increases the size of an anthro which can cause all sort of problems in a modern, crowded society. Injuries (getting caught), accidents (knocking something over), personal space, etc. are all topics I'd love to see explored. I could easily see a bushy tail being a status symbol, whereas a thin one (or the lack of one) could be seen as lower class due to necessity or injury during manual labor

Anonymous Sun 02 Aug 2020 14:18:52 No.31870560 Report
Quoted By: >>31870637 >>31870842
>>31870406
continuing
An anthro doing manual labor would have a massive advantage a human wouldn't. The moment arm upon a limb might be the same, but motion involves the whole body. Like I said, that you only understand that by saying "amputate it" reveals inexperience as well as ignores a prime complication of amputations - neuromas.

Focusing on the "realistic", as you say, determines the balance of sensory and physical traits. If anything, tails in one of my stories are how the anthros compete with humans that have an upper body better suited for manipulation. Do I go into the half the depth noted here? Nope, because none of the characters would infodump that. Now a future story...lets just say there's a reason for a certain doctor to explain a few things to a poor human.

Then again, one of the underpinnings I started from is everything moves to a common range of possibilities. A canid would have their sense of smell decrease due to a greater distance from the ground. A primate would shift from muscle insertions being focused on power to fine motor control. An anthro with a larger tail would use it to reduce the energy required for any and every motion.

Anonymous Sun 02 Aug 2020 14:27:02 No.31870637 Report
Quoted By: >>31870842
>>31870406
>>31870560


Actually the reason that armor was universal among the cultures that had the means to make it is because Speed and Agility dont make up for the ability to deflect and tank a attack that would have skewered you.

Until mature firearms technology was reached and offense started to outdistance the defensive capabilities of armors, people that could afford armor and were expected to be in battle, wore armor.

The speed/agility tank idea is a meme borne from fantasy/anime, Certainly, people fought and killed each others with little to minimal armor but that was in cases where they either could not afford armor, where they could not use armor, or where they were forbidden from using armor. But against a peer opponent you cannot expect to be any faster or more agile than him and as such need a way to be able to either outrange him or tank the damage.

As for the proprioception argument that too is incorrect. Certainly you can learn to some minor degree to know your body and its whereabouts. This do not mean that it is a proper substitute for not actually having a limb capable going into the whirling cogs and rolling presses of the 17-1800 century equivalent factories. People worked decades in these factories and had their hands and arms within eyesight still lost bodyparts with alarming frequency.

Another thing to consider is grappling.

You don't wear a cape in combat because it gets in the way and it's something for the enemy to grab and use as leverage. A large tail would have the same problem, something for the opponent to grab and use against them. Something a human does not have.

Also if it gets cut off (something that's easy to do) it would hurt quite a bit. It might not be fatal but it would be very distracting and make it hard to focus.

Well since your here, and asking here, buckle up:
>Trying to do classical epic
>writes poetry with no rhyme or stanza structure

Look at any classical epic

>story opens describing Gligamesh, Uruk and the problems of the city
Beowulf
>Beowulf the great warrior comes to the aid of the Danes to fight a monster that is plaguing them
The Iliad
>Begins with Achilles deciding to go to war to appease the gods
Epic poems dive right the fuck in and I don't even know what your story is about.

also this sentence
>The geometry of the room explained something; something I had to learn with the waking mind; I never understood Euclidean geometry, yet using it, this tree was designed.
Might be the most pretentious thing I've ever read outside of fan fiction. How the fuck does someone know the phrase "Euclidean geometry" if they have no knowledge of it? You can't write that in the first person and make sense of it. It feels like this entire sentence exists so that you could use the word Euclidean and it doesn't even fit. The addiction to colons and semicolons are not exactly indicative of mastery either. An abrasive sentence structure had best convey meaning and yours do not.

H.P Lovecraft published books all throughout his life, that is not unheard of. He just wasn't popular until after his death. You have published nothing, not even in the era of self publishing where it is so cheap and easy to garner a following. You keep doubling down on your mastery and your years. Years do not equal quality or improvement, it is entirely possible to do something badly for a long time. That is why you have to measure progress with something other than your own self assessment, such as publishing or respecting outside criticism.
